_prev_prog_3.CH_OtherChanges: DCS graphic changes, seismic repairs and procedure updates

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
A. Chevron Corporate Policy on Protecting People and the Environment

Chevron has built a culture of safety and environmental stewardship that strives to achieve world-class performance and prevent all incidents. Our workforce believes that incidents are preventable, and we have policies, processes, tools and behavioral expectations in place to assist us in achieving that goal. 

Chevrons vision is to be the global energy company most admired for its people, partnership and performance.

Chevrons safety culture is based on our Tenets of Operation, a code of conduct that employees and contractors use, and that supervisors and managers reinforce. These Tenets are based on two key principles:

Do it safely or not at all; and
Theres always time to do it right.

Another key aspect of Chevrons safety culture is stop-work authority. Every member of Chevrons workforce  whether employee or contractor-has the authority and responsibility to stop work any time they see a condition that may present a risk to people, process safety, or to the environment. Additionally, the employees are empowered to recommend to the operator in charge to shut down a plant using Stop Work Authority due to a Process Safety Hazard.

B. Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled

The Refinery is in the City of Richmond, Contra Costa County, State of California. The Refinery is the largest refinery in the Bay Area with an average throughput capacity of approximately 245,000 barrels of crude oil per day. The Refinery covers approximately 2,900 acres. There are approximately 1,300 employees at the Refinery with additional support fulfilled by contractors as needed for special events such as turnarounds or projects.    

The Refinery  is located on a peninsula bordered by the San Francisco Bay to the north and west, the San Pablo Bay to the northeast, an acid regeneration facility to the southeast and the City of Richmond to the northwest, east and south. Point Molate

and a quarry are situated nearby on the western edge of the peninsula, the Port of Richmonds Terminal 4 property is located on the northwestern tip, and the Point San Pablo Yacht Harbor occupies a small section of the northern edge of the peninsula. The area immediately surrounding the refinery is nearly all industrial with the neighborhoods of Point Richmond to the south, Atchison Village to the southeast, North Richmond to the northeast, and the Iron Triangle to the east being the most proximal to the facility.

The Refinerys primary business is to make transportation fuels from crude oil. The transportation fuel products produced at the Refinery include gasoline, jet fuel, and diesel fuel. The Refinery also produces lubricating oils and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG). Several byproducts are produced by the Refinerys production processes, including sulfur and anhydrous ammonia, which are recovered from sulfur and nitrogen contained in the crude oil. The EPA and CalARP regulated substances present at the refinery include flammable hydrocarbons, hydrogen sulfide (H2S) and ammonia (NH3).

C. The General Accidental Release Prevention Program & Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

1. Management System   
The Refinerys senior managers have the overall responsibility for adherence to all government regulations, including CalARP, EPA RMP, Cal/OSHA PSM and RISO. The Refinerys management system provides a framework to ensure Refinery personnel can integrate all the regulatory requirements into Refinery work processes.

Leadership 
The single largest factor for success at the Richmond Refinery is leadership. The Refinerys leaders are focused not only on getting results, but getting results the right way with behaviors in accordance with Chevrons values. They are accountable for stewarding the Refinerys RMP processes, and for both enabling and delivering performance. 

By their actions, the Refinerys leaders: 
- Cascade, manage and drive execution; 
- Reinforce the pro

cess safety culture; 
- Instill operational discipline  every task the right way, every time; and
- Ensure that they and the entire Refinery workforce comply with prevention program requirements. 

Through personal example, the Refinerys leaders demonstrate that zero  whether related to process safety, personal safety, health, environmental, reliability, or efficiency incidents  is attainable.

Expectations & Policies
Expectations include compliance with all government laws and regulations. Refinery Instructions (RIs) are the primary method of setting and communicating expectations for the prevention program elements at the Refinery. These instructions are available on the Refinery Information Server, which is the Refinerys internal web page with pertinent information accessible to all personnel. Each RI is owned and maintained by an appropriate organization within the Refinery. The manager of each organization dedicates subject matter experts (SMEs) to periodically review and update the RIs. As part of the RI update process, all employees are given an opportunity to share input on potential changes. PSM-related RIs also include consultation with the United Steel Workers (USW) Union. After the refinery SMEs, employee input and union feedback; the updates are completed and each RI is reviewed and approved by the manager who owns that element and forwarded to senior managers for review and approval before taking effect. Refinery employees responsible for RI modifications must communicate those changes to all affected employees.

Vision  
The Refinerys management system begins with defining a vision of success and setting objectives. The vison and objectives drive the Refinerys Business Plan. The Refinerys Vision is to achieve and sustain world-class performance. There is no measure of the Refinerys performance with a higher priority than operating safely, reliably, and with concern for the health and well-being of the workforce, surrounding communities and

afety and environmental metrics to set targets and identify 
improvement opportunities; and
- Review of progress on action items from audits and safety meetings. Review is primarily 
tracked in databases, dashboards or in meeting minutes.

Resources 
Necessary expertise to support the Refinerys work processes is provided through dedicated organizations such as Technical, Maintenance and Reliability, Health Environment and Safety and Process Safety. These groups possess a combination of technical training and practical hands-on experience which is necessary to not only solve problems and implement solutions, but to effectively communicate and enforce the need to implement the various prevention program elements. When a special situation requires outside expertise, necessary resources are assembled from other Chevron refineries, operating companies, or contract specialists.

2. Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
The prevention programs described in the following section represent integrated, administrative controls intended to ensure the safety of workers, the public, and the environment. All covered processes have control systems designed to maintain operating parameters (temperature, pressure, flow, level) within allowable limits. The covered processes are also equipped with alarms to alert personnel when the operating parameters exceed allowable limits. The Refinery uses procedures and trains personnel to ensure the correct response to the alarms. 

The Refinery has the following chemical-specific engineering controls to mitigate accidental releases:

Liquefied Petroleum Gas
The LPG storage area has been designed to minimize the risk of releasing flammable hydrocarbons to the atmosphere by providing high equipment reliability, minimizing the number of connections, avoiding unnecessary equipment, and protecting against inadvertent damage or failure. Some of the specific prevention and mitigation safeguards are described below.
- The LPG storage spheres are located

away from the refinery perimeter to minimize the effect on 
   the public in the event of a release;
- Spheres are separated by a distance equal to at least the diameter of the larger sphere;
- Each sphere is equipped with a firewater deluge system to cool the vessel to prevent failure in 
   the event of a fire;
- The LPG storage area is equipped with alarms, pressure relief devices, and emergency block 
   valves to prevent or limit the severity of a release;
- Each sphere is equipped with a fusible link valve, which is a check valve that will automatically 
   close during a fire and isolate the sphere from all other systems
- The surrounding area is equipped with fixed fire monitors; and
- The drainage near the spheres would cause released liquid to drain away from the spheres and 
   the rest of the refinery and would minimize the surface area to reduce the amount of 
   evaporation.

Anhydrous Ammonia
The NH3 storage area has also been designed to minimize the risk of releasing anhydrous ammonia. Some of the specific prevention and mitigation safeguards are described below.
- The ammonia storage is located away from the refinery perimeter to minimize the effect on the 
   public in the event of a release;
- Each storage vessel is equipped with a firewater deluge system to reduce the vapor cloud and 
   cool the vessel in the event of a fire;
- The NH3 storage area is equipped with a NH3 leak detection system with both audible and 
   control room alarms;
- The NH3 storage area is equipped with alarms, pressure relief devices, excess flow valves, and 
   emergency block valves to prevent or limit the severity of a release;
- The NH3 storage area is encircled by a firewater-monitor fog system. One large water fog spray 
   can be remotely operated; and
- The drainage in the storage area is such that a release of liquid drains away from the storage 
   vessels and minimizes the surface area to reduce the amount of evaporation.

Hydrogen Sulfide
The processes cont

aining H2S are equipped with safety systems designed to prevent or minimize releases of H2S. The safety systems in place are described below:
- Each SRU train is equipped with either a safety shutdown system or a shutdown interlock 
   system designed to protect personnel and equipment and prevent the potential release of H2S. - Each of these systems shuts down key pieces of equipment automatically when certain 
   operating parameters are outside of established operating limits.
- The SRU is equipped with an emergency quench water system, which can be operated 
   automatically, to protect equipment in the event of a fire.
- Each process that contains H2S is equipped with alarms, pressure relief devices, and 
   emergency block valves to prevent or limit the severity of a release.
- Each H2S Recovery Plant can be routed to an emergency scrubber in the event of an SRU 
   shutdown.
- Each process that contains H2S is equipped with an H2S area monitoring system that will 
   detect ambient levels of H2S and activate alarm systems. The alarm systems will indicate the 
   location and concentration of H2S leaks.
- The Refinery has H2S monitors located along the Refinery perimeter to alert Refinery personnel 
   if H2S is detected.

3. Prevention Program Elements
a. Process Safety Information (PSI)
PSI is developed during the design and construction of each process. PSI is updated as needed when any changes or additions are made and it is retained for the life of the process or equipment plus 30 years, consistent with the Refinerys record retention requirements for PHA files. The development, dissemination, and use of PSI are vital to the effective operation of the Refinery. Personnel use PSI regarding chemical hazards, equipment specifications, and operating limits in daily operation and strategic decision making. Accurate and complete PSI is readily accessible to employees. Relevant PSI is available upon request to affected contractors.

Refinery procedures guide emp

hanism Review for applicable processes

c. Safeguard Protection Analysis (SPA)
The Refinerys Layers of Protection Analysis (LOPA) program was initiated in 2014 to assess the effectiveness of existing PHA safeguards and recommended safeguards to reduce the probability and/or severity of a catastrophic release.

LOPA is a risk assessment tool that uses a semi-quantitative method to evaluate qualifying process unit hazard scenarios to determine if sufficient Independent Protection Layers (IPLs) are available to protect against process safety accidents and to protect personnel, the general public and the environment.

An Independent Protection Layer is an approved and validated safeguard available to prevent initiation of a hazard scenario or escalation of its consequence. IPLs may be passive or active and preventative or mitigating, and may include containment areas, critical alarms, Safety Instrumented Functions (SIFs), Pressure Relief Devices (PRDs), gas detectors / deluge systems with automatic action and Process Control System (PCS) loop functions, among others.  

d. Operating Procedures   
Clearly written safe work practices and operating procedures, especially for high-risk critical tasks, are important for the safe operation of the facility and to reduce the likelihood of a release of hazardous chemicals or energy that could impact employees, the community or the environment.    

Safe Work Practices include, but are not limited to:
- Hot Work and General Work Permits 
- Control of Entry into Process Areas 
- Control of Hazardous Energy (includes lockout/tagout and lines/equipment opening)
- General Procedures for Entering/Working in Confined Spaces 

Electronic copies of operating procedures are available to all employees. Paper copies of emergency operating procedures are available in the control room of each process unit.
The Refinerys operating manuals include the following sections and appendices:
- Process description; 
- Normal operations, including st

leak, release or discharge is occurring; or 
(2) Isolate any vessel, piping, and equipment where a leak, spill or discharge is occurring; or 
(3) Follow established criteria for handling leaks, spills, or discharges that are designed to provide a level of protection that is functionally equivalent to, or safer than, shutting down or isolating the process.

e. Training    
The Refinery training program ensures employees have necessary skills and knowledge to perform their jobs in an incident-free manner, and in compliance with all applicable laws, regulations, and policies.

One of the purposes of the Refinerys written training plan is to provide affected personnel with an understanding of the types and causes of potential incidents or deviations within the process and the hazards associated with the process.

The Refinery training program is comprised of the following:
- Fundamentals training;
- Plant or equipment specific formal training;
- Training provided as a result of an MOC, which includes training on updated or new procedures;
- Refresher training; and
- Training documentation

All operators receive training in safe work practices   and basic operating principles prior to assignment. The operators receive training specific to the operations of each process once they are assigned to a process unit. The training criteria are documented in job dimension documents that list the knowledge required (e.g., safe operating limits, safety system setpoints) and skills to demonstrate (e.g., emergency shutdown, lockout/tagout procedures). Various means are used to verify competency, including written and oral examinations, demonstrations, and on-the-job training. Documentation of the training is forwarded to the Learning & Development (L&D) Department for filing and tracking.

Refresher training on specific operating procedures (e.g., normal operations, startup, shutdown), critical, seldom-done tasks, emergency procedures, MOC reviews, safe work practices, (i.e., in pla

nt hot work, lockout/tagout), and company-wide practices is provided.
- Computer based training on job specific PSM requirements 
- Simulator or oral discussion / demonstration when applicable
- Monthly hypotheticals or table top drills
- Computer based training on safe work practices
- Just in time training on startup, shutdown and related procedures before turnarounds
- Process safety topics delivered by Supervisors

The Refinerys current training schedule was developed with employee consultation and allows refresher training to be conducted at a minimum of every three years. Training documentation is tracked in the training database, crew turnover logs and safety database (hypotheticals).

Training may also be required as a result of the MOC process. The type of training is determined according to the complexity of the change (e.g., email notification, hands on/simulator training, classroom training). Training records are forwarded to and maintained by the L&D Department. The RBU is responsible for ensuring that the necessary training is conducted prior to implementation of a change.

A PSM General Awareness training class was developed in conjunction with USW Health and Safety representatives to ensure all affected employees are aware of and understand all Prevention Program elements. Employees and employee representatives participating in a specialized team receive just in time training in the Program element(s) relevant to that team.

f. Mechanical Integrity 
Proper design and maintenance of equipment and safety systems is essential to prevent releases of highly hazardous materials.

The mechanical integrity program applies to fixed and rotating equipment, instrumentation, and electrical systems. This includes pressure vessels, storage tanks, piping systems (including piping components such as valves), compressors, pumps, pressure relief devices, and vent systems, all of which are inspected following industry guidelines. The mechanical integrity program als

o applies to emergency shutdown systems and process controls, including monitoring devices, sensors, alarms, and interlocks.

The Refinerys mechanical integrity program consists of the following:

- Quality assurance procedures  Members of the Technical, Maintenance and Reliability, and Procurement organizations develop and maintain purchasing documents for new and modified equipment. They review all new equipment against the purchasing documents to ensure that the equipment is fabricated in accordance with the specifications. They also conduct appropriate checks and inspections to ensure that the equipment is installed properly and is consistent with the design specifications and the manufacturers instructions. In addition, all personnel and work involved with welding follows API, ASME, AWS and/or NBIC approved written QA/QC procedures. 

The preceding elements of the quality assurance program are often performed in conjunction with the MOC and PSSR programs. The Purchasing and Materials Management Department, in conjunction with Technical, Maintenance and Reliability personnel, develops and maintains purchasing documents for spare parts. This ensures that all maintenance materials and spare parts are suitable for the process.

- Written maintenance procedures for process equipment  Written procedures and checklists (including step-by-step instructions) are developed for maintaining process equipment. Copies of the procedures and checklists used are available through the Refinery Information Server from the L&D EOM home page. Changes or additions to procedures identified during maintenance activities are communicated to the L&D Department and the procedures are updated by the respective owner utilizing the MOC process. Regularly scheduled maintenance (preventative maintenance) requests are automatically generated by a computer-based maintenance work management system. Non-preventive maintenance activities are also performed through the work management system (i

.e., operators and engineers submit work requests to be scheduled by the Maintenance Planner/Scheduler). The Maintenance employees complete the work order documentation, and the maintenance history records are updated in the work management system. 

The Refinerys EMMS ensures that maintenance procedures and manuals are both current and accurate. The EMMS database provides employees a method to review and update documents according to a regular schedule. Maintenance procedures are reviewed every three years.

- Maintenance employee training  Maintenance skills training is provided to new hires over a 3-year period and includes assessments. Additional skills training is provided on an as-needed basis or when required by applicable codes and standards. The L&D Department maintains documentation of skills training (e.g., union training program, community college training, specialty equipment training) and compliance training for maintenance employees. During initial employee training and refresher training, maintenance employees are provided with an overview of the process, the hazards associated with the process, and safe work practices. The L&D Department maintains initial and refresher training records including content of training, instructor, and means used to verify competency. All welding related work and records are carefully monitored and controlled through the Refinery Inspection Department in accordance with ASME, AWS and NBIC requirements.

- Inspection, Testing and Preventative Maintenance (ITPM) for critical equipment  Inspection, testing and preventative maintenance tasks and frequency of tasks for each piece of critical equipment were developed and documented by the Maintenance and Reliability organization. These ITPMs and their frequency are based upon jurisdictional requirements, manufacturers recommendations, recognized and general accepted good engineering practices, operating history, and failure prediction and prevention analysis. Completed in

spection and test documents include the inspectors name, date of the inspection or test, identification of the equipment, inspection and test procedures.  The results of the inspection or test are retained by the Maintenance and Reliability organization. Equipment inspectors or reliability analysts review the results of each inspection or test to ascertain whether the equipment is within the acceptable limits and to determine if the frequency of the inspections should be adjusted. Equipment outside of the acceptable limits is removed, repaired or replaced unless temporary protective measures can be put in place until the deficiencies are corrected. Inspection and test results are maintained for the life of the equipment. Some examples of inspections and tests include internal and external inspections, thickness monitoring, ultrasonic/radiography inspection, hydrotesting and infra-red scans. Instrumentation and control systems are also tested to ensure they will function as intended.

g. Management of Change (MOC)
A change made in one part of the process may have unintended effects on other parts of the process because the Refinery is an integrated system. These changes are therefore appropriately scrutinized to avoid adverse effects to workers, the public, and to the environment.
 
The Refinery has implemented a written MOC procedure which ensures that all changes to the following are properly managed:
- Process chemicals (i.e., raw materials, intermediate products, solvents);
- Technology (i.e., operating parameters, catalysts, rates);
- Equipment (i.e., materials of construction, equipment specifications); and
- Procedures (i.e., emergency response, maintenance, operating) 

MOC does not apply to replacement in kind, which is defined as a replacement that satisfies the design specifications for the equipment being replaced.

Changes are classified as permanent, temporary, or emergency. Emergency changes are allowed during off-hours and holidays; however, at a m

-place, property damage, or environmental damage. 

Communicating the five-year accident history to the public informs the community of the factors causing or contributing to accidental releases, the onsite and offsite impacts of accidental releases, and the procedural and technological changes implemented to minimize the possibility of recurrence. The intent of this information exchange is to create an informed community while also documenting that accidental releases are investigated, and concrete changes are made to protect against recurrence.

There have been no incidents in the last five years that meet the above criteria. 

E. The Emergency Response Program 
The Refinery maintains an emergency response program designed to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. As part of the emergency response program:

- There is a written Emergency Response Plan (ERP) for responding to accidental chemical releases, including releases of regulated substances. The ERP is reviewed to ensure that it remains accurate and current. Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties; 

- There are procedures that address maintenance, inspection, and testing of emergency response equipment;

- The Refinery works closely with local emergency responders (primarily the Richmond Fire Department and/or CCHMP) in preparing for emergencies; and

- There are procedures for notifying the public and local emergency response agencies about accidental releases.

Emergency Response Plan (ERP)
The ERP addresses all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release does occur, and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements. The ERP is documented in a series of RIs and is available to all employees. Hard copies of the E

viduals have completed all required Evaluations and Actions identified on the MOC form before the change is put into service.

The MOC cannot be closed and will remain open until any procedure update is verified as posted to the Refinery EOM and any Process Safety Information is verified as updated on the web.

MOC records and documentation of completion of the tasks and reviews are maintained for the life of the process plus 30 years.

The Refinery also has a written policy for managing organizational changes. The purpose of the Management of Organizational Change (MOOC) Policy is to ensure the proper management of organizational changes exceeding 90 calendar days with the intent to prevent negative impact on worker safety and health, the community, and the environment.

Positions affected by the MOOC Policy include:
- Operations, including supervisors and engineers with direct responsibilities associated with processing units;
- Emergency response;
- Maintenance;
- Health and safety; and
- Contractors in permanent positions.

The MOOC Policy   shall be used to analyze (a) a decrease in the number of positions or number of personnel, (b) a 15 % increase in the duties of a position, (c) reorganization of a department or substantive changes in the responsibilities of positions, and (d) a change to the shift duration or job classification of a position.

h. Pre-Startup Safety Review (PSSR)    
PSSRs provide a system of checks and verifications, independent of the MOC process, to ensure that equipment is suitable for service and meets required specifications prior to startup to prevent the release of highly hazardous materials. 

The PSSR process takes place prior to startup of a new unit or the startup of an existing unit after a shutdown/turnaround event where the equipment is opened, or when a system/unit is idled for 6 months or longer. Changes requiring an MOC may also trigger a PSSR. 

The PSSR facilitator convenes a team with knowledge of the process and experti

e audit team utilizes audit protocols to consistently perform the following:
- An assessment of the written prevention program elements;
- A review of records (i.e., completed hot work permits, MOC documents, incident investigations, equipment records) to assess implementation of the written prevention program elements;
- Interviews with employees and their representatives to assess their understanding of applicable programs (for example, whether personnel have a basic understanding of the mechanical integrity program); and
- Interviews with key personnel (those with primary responsibility for each element within the prevention program)
- Consultations with operators that have expertise and experience in each process audited

The audit team prepares a written report documenting audit team qualifications, scope, methods used, questions asked to assess each program element, findings and recommendations. The written report is available for employees and employee representatives. Any written comments from employees regarding the report will get a response, in writing, within 60 calendar days. The Refinery retains the three most recent compliance audit reports. Corrective actions developed by prevention program element owners are either completed within one and one half (1.5) years after the compliance audit report is certified by the Refinery Manager or added to the next planned turnaround.

j. Incident Investigation  
The Refinerys incident investigation program includes procedures for investigating each incident that results in, or could reasonably have resulted in, a catastrophic release.

Incident investigations provide the Refinery with the means to identify root causes or systemic factors and implement solutions to prevent future incidents.

RBU Managers are responsible for ensuring that personnel in their area promptly report any abnormal event(s) or near misses, including those with catastrophic release potential. All incidents are reported into the Refinerys

Incident database. Personnel trained in the methodology to be used (includes 5 Why, Learning Team, Safeguard Analysis for Events (SAFE), Why Tree and TapRoot®) are assigned as investigation team leader and/or investigation team facilitator. The experience and number of the other team members are dependent upon the nature of the incident. Typically, the incident investigation teams are comprised of a team leader and other employees (including contract employees) knowledgeable in the operation, design, and maintenance of the process. Catastrophic releases require the use of the TapRoot® methodology (root cause analysis), which incorporates human factors in the investigation process. 

The incident investigation team leader is responsible for initiating the investigation as soon as possible, but no later than 48 hours from the time of the incident or near miss. Team members, with team leader/facilitator guidance, collect and analyze facts, identify root causes, develop appropriate solutions to avoid repeat occurrences, and prepare the initial investigation report. 

The investigation report is entered into the Refinerys computerized incident database. Lessons learned are communicated to the refinery employees to prevent future occurrences. The Refinery regularly reviews metrics to prevent corrective actions from becoming overdue and tracks the status of investigations, so they are completed in a timely fashion. Incident investigation reports are retained for five years.

Incident investigation results are reviewed with employees (including contract employees) whose job tasks are relevant to the findings in regular safety meetings, in other acceptable forums, or through incident bulletins. The management team discusses incidents that resulted in significant consequences as part of the daily safety discussions. 
The final report includes the following: date and time of incident; date and time investigation began; a description of the incident; the factors that caused or

ivities such as Health & Safety Evaluations, training and PSSRs, which are documented in the MOC database; and
(g) Submission of safety concerns through Green Cards. This program allows all employees and contractors to anonymously report hazards and receive feedback within 30 calendar days. The Refinery promptly prioritizes and resolves issues that could result in death or serious physical harm.

The Refinery has Health and Safety Representatives and a Human and Organizational Performance (HOP) Representative that are all members of the USW union. They are invited to participate in the design, development, implementation and continual improvement of Accidental Release Prevention elements.

l. Hot Work Permits 
Controlling ignition sources is vital to the Refinerys Risk Management Plan. The hot work element prevents inadvertent ignition of flammables or combustibles when performing jobs such as welding and ensures that any fires which may occur can be readily suppressed and extinguished. Management personnel must authorize any hot work (e.g., cutting, grinding, burning, welding, brazing) to be performed in a unit and ensure appropriate safety precautions are taken prior to initiation of the work. The Refinerys hot work permit program requires that employees complete permit requirements certifying that the applicable portions of the fire prevention and protection requirements are implemented prior to beginning hot work operations.

The fire prevention procedure restricts hot work in certain areas. When grinding, burning, welding, or brazing work is needed in these areas, an ignition source permit must be initiated by the Maintenance supervisor and approved by the local Operations supervisor. The permit is terminated when continued use of the ignition source is hazardous, when conditions of its issuance change, or when the permitted hot work has been inactive for more than two hours (unless tests show that conditions are still non-hazardous).

The permit contains the

following information:
- The effective date and time;
- The place of use;
- The hours during which the source of ignition may be used;
- The specific location or piece of equipment where the source of ignition will be used;
- The nature of the source of ignition; and
- Any special precautions or limitations to be observed before, during, or after the use of the source of ignition, including the need for a fire watch and fire hoses or extinguishers. The criteria for needing a fire watch are identified in Refinery procedures. The responsibilities and authority of the fire watch are to continuously monitor assigned job(s), extinguish incipient stage fires, sound fire alarm when necessary, and to use Stop Work Authority if they think that work being performed is unsafe.

Trained personnel from Emergency Services, Operations, and Maintenance perform an inspection of the area to ensure the following prior to authorization of hot work:
- The source of ignition is safe to use. Only approved apparatus shall be used. 
- Personnel performing the hot work (including contractors) are informed of the hazards and properly trained. 
- Concentrations of flammable gases or vapors are less than 5% of the lower explosive limit.
- Combustible materials in areas that will be exposed during hot work are protected or relocated.
- Proper fire extinguishing equipment is available to employees performing the hot work.
- Personnel in the control room are notified prior to initiation of the hot work to make them aware of the ignition source. This awareness allows personnel in the control room to quickly contact the fire watch and personnel performing hot work if continued use of the source of ignition becomes hazardous.

m. Contractors  
The Refinery contractor program ensures that safety issues are addressed during contractor selection and that Chevron and the contract company share responsibility for the safety of all employees. The Refinery and all contract companies are jointly responsible

e audits is adjusted according to the type of work performed (e.g., welding inside of a vessel). The Business Owner assigned to a contract ensures that the contract employer provides proper training and maintains documentation for each of its contract employees. The Business Owner also monitors performance (i.e., compliance with Refinery safe work practices, knowledge of types of work, and the hazards involved). Documentation of audits and on-site evaluations is maintained for a minimum of five years within the COEM database.

It is critical for contractors and Refinery personnel to be aware of any unique hazards that may be encountered prior to performing work; therefore, a Hazard Analysis and Pre-Job Briefing is performed through the Permit to Work (PTW) process. Evaluation and communication of hazards is also accomplished via safe work practice processes (e.g., lockout/tagout and confined space entry).

n. Hierarchy of Hazard Control Analysis (HCA) 
The expectation of the Richmond Refinery is to focus on what can be done to eliminate process safety hazards before considering how to control them. To that end Richmond uses five levels within the inherent safety hierarchy: 1st Order Inherent, 2nd Order Inherent, Passive Safeguards, Active Safeguards, and Procedural Safeguards. Any of these risk management strategies may contribute to the overall safety of a process.

Chevron implements HCA for the following:
- Qualifying PHA Recommendations
- New Facilities, New Processes, and New Process Units
- Major Changes
- Major Incident Recommendations

o. Process Safety Culture Assessment  
Process Safety Culture at the Refinery is a combination of group values and behaviors that reflect whether there is a collective commitment by leaders and individuals to emphasize process safety over competing goals, to ensure protection of people and the environment.

The purpose of the Safety Culture Assessment is to assist in identifying pervasive attitudes or beliefs regarding risk to

lerance in the work place with the intent to improve safety culture and decrease the number and severity of incidents. Process Safety Culture Assessments offer a gauge to the effectiveness of our health and safety programs by providing a view of attitudes, perceptions, competencies and patterns of behavior.   

The Refinery applies approved data gathering techniques including Written Surveys, Focus Groups, and Observations to assess Process Safety Culture. The data gathering technique is determined during the planning of the Safety Culture Assessment and documentation of the selection of the data gathering technique and target participation levels is maintained. The data gathering technique will be selected based on how effective it may be to assess the required components and meet the target participation levels. 

The Refinery maintains a schedule for performing safety culture assessments. Interim assessment timing is also maintained on the schedule. The revalidations occur every five years.  Interim assessment will be performed between the five-year assessment time frame. 

At the start of a Process Safety Culture Assessment, a team of refinery employees with different backgrounds, including a USW Health and Safety representative or steward is identified to develop, implement the Process Safety Culture Assessment and evaluate the results. A Refinery Subject Matter Expert leads the Process Safety Culture Assessment team to ensure that the Safety Culture Assessment is performed as expected and as described in the written program. Previous Safety Culture Assessment results may be reviewed by the team. The Refinery Instruction contains direction for how results will be evaluated.

Once issues have been identified sufficiently to act upon, updates and additions may be made to the design, execution, evaluation, and continuous improvement plan to affect changes to safety-related behaviors.

p. Human Factors Program
The Refinerys Human Factors Program looks at the inter

actions between workers, processes/equipment and management systems. The Refinery is committed to applying a systematic approach to identify and resolve human factor issues to prevent accidental releases of highly hazardous materials. 

A human factors analysis is applied to the following prevention program elements: 
- Process Hazards Analysis; 
- Hierarchy of Hazards Control Analysis
- Major Change
- Operating and Maintenance Procedures; 
- Management of Organizational Changes; and
- Root Cause Analysis.

q. Stop Work Authority 
The Refinery has a history of using Stop and Pause Work Authority for safety.  Employees feel they can stop unsafe work.  A Refinery Protocol is available on the Refinery Intranet.  The protocol defines when documentation is required and the tool that is used. The protocol gives all employees, including employees of contractors the authority to:
- Refuse to perform a task where doing so could reasonably result in death or serious physical harm;
- Recommend to the operator in charge of a unit that an operation or process be partially or completely shut down, based on a process safety hazard; and, 

The protocol also gives the qualified operator in charge of a unit the authority to partially or completely shut down an operation or process, based on a process safety hazard.

r. Accidental Release Prevention Program Management System 
The Richmond Refinery PSM Policy includes the following:
- Job descriptions and roles for each prevention program element
- Organizational chart
- A written communication plan for safety, operations and maintenance information
- Policies and procedures for findings, recommendations and corrective actions 
- Process safety performance indicators reported to CCHMP

D. The Five-Year Accident History
The Refinery keeps a five-year history of accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in onsite deaths, injuries, or significant property damage, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in

RP, and manuals of emergency plans and procedures, are also maintained throughout the Refinery. 

The ERP is reviewed annually by the Manager of the Chevron Fire Department and updated to ensure that it remains accurate and current. Every employee receives training via Computer Based Training (CBT) in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties.

The ERP includes the chemical-specific emergency response procedures for releases of RMP-regulated chemicals. The chemical-specific emergency response plans identify the characteristics of the chemical, emergency response and first aid procedures, and the community notification system. These plans also identify concentrations of chemicals that would trigger specific types of emergency response and when to notify the public.

In addition, all employees are trained on the ERP upon initial assignment. The level of emergency response training corresponds to the emergency response duties of the employee. 

In addition to the ERP, the Refinery also has local Emergency Action Plans (EAPs), which are posted in all buildings and operating area control rooms. All employees or contractors entering a process area must review the EAP for that area prior to entry. The EAP summarizes the first actions that are to be taken in the event of an emergency (e.g., stay clear of area, call emergency number, move indoors, etc.) and the means for reporting fires and emergencies (a single three-digit phone number). The EAP also has guidelines for sheltering-in-place, evacuations, and earthquakes, as well as maps with evacuation routes and meeting places.

Emergency Operating Procedures, which are a part of the prevention program, are another critical component of emergency preparedness. These procedures outline the steps to be taken to control or shut down a process unit in the event of an emergency (e.g., fire, earthquake, release, etc.). Operators for the process are trained in these procedures.

The Refinery

also has various mitigation safeguards in place to minimize impact of chemical or toxic releases. Examples include H2S scrubbers, emergency deluge systems and administrative controls to manage ammonia and LPG inventory.

Chevron Fire Department
The Chevron Fire Departments responsibilities include inspections of fire-related equipment, permit authorization for hot work and confined space entry, security, and a variety of other tasks related to fire prevention and emergency response. The Chevron Fire Department consists of full-time personnel and volunteers from the Operations, Maintenance, and Technical Divisions. Each volunteer member receives approximately 100 hours of training each year. 

Full-time Emergency Response personnel are trained to handle fires in process plants, building fires, storage tank fires, wild land fires, or fires related to transportation modes, including ships, barges, tank cars, railcars and automobiles. All full-time personnel are trained in various rescue situations including confined space, high angle, heavy rescue procedures and auto extrication. In addition, all full-time members are certified Hazardous Material Technicians. There are also Hazardous Materials Specialists within the department.  All are qualified to deal with any hazardous material incident including any oil spills at the ship and barge loading facilities. Full-time personnel also respond to medical emergencies; many members are California State Certified Emergency Medical Technicians (EMTs). 

The volunteer personnel of Chevron Fire Department add depth and resourcefulness to the organization given its diverse background. Volunteers are all trained as Industrial Responders.  Training for this group enables them to respond to fires in process plants, storage tank fires, or fires related to transportation modes, including ships, barges, tank cars, and railcars. Volunteer personnel are trained in confined space rescue. All volunteer personnel complete an Industrial Hazm

at Technician course enabling them to respond to on-site hazardous material incidents including any oil spills at the ship and barge loading facilities

A variety of emergency response equipment exists at the Refinery and includes 25 emergency response vehicles (including fire trucks), 2500 fire extinguishers, water deluge systems, in-plant stationary fire monitors, fixed foam systems, and a water fog system. All of this equipment is maintained, inspected, and tested as outlined in the Chevron Fire Department Procedures and Policies.

Coordination
The Refinery conducts emergency drills in which an offsite responding agency (Richmond Fire Department and/or CCHMP), the Chevron Fire Department, and non-responding employees work together to resolve the given scenario. This pre-planning activity ensures that the members of the responding agencies are familiar with the Refinery, the hazards of the regulated substances, the resources available at the Refinery, and the locations of these resources. It also clearly identifies the capabilities and limitations of each responding agency. These drills are conducted at least once a year.

The Refinery also works closely with the CCHMP for any necessary response to hazardous material releases (such as downwind air monitoring) and to alert the public in case of accidental releases, fires, or explosions in accordance with CCHMPs Emergency Response Area Plan. The Refinery worked with CCHMP to establish the Community Warning System (CWS) and the Telephone Emergency Notification System (TENS) zones, which provide incident notification to the community.

The Chevron Fire Department also provides mutual aid to the City of Richmond Fire Department and responds outside of the Refinery within the City of Richmond whenever asked to do so by the city fire department. The Chevron Fire Department also belongs to an industrial mutual aid organization, Petrochemical Mutual Aid Organization (PMAO), and has responded to other oil companies and che

mical plants during emergencies. Likewise, the emergency response resources of the other companies in PMAO are available for an emergency at the Refinery, if needed.

Notification
The Emergency Response Program has plans and procedures in place for notifying employees, on-site and off-site emergency responders, government agencies, the community, and local hospitals in the event of a release. These procedures are available on the Refinery Information Server.

Upon the first detection of a release or other emergency, an employee is required to call the central emergency phone number, which initiates the emergency response. Alarms or sirens are used to notify personnel of an emergency, and appropriate actions (e.g., shelter-in-place) are taken according to the EAP.

The Refinery has an internal Refinery-wide alarm system consisting of multiple sirens and loudspeakers to alert personnel to any incidents that may have an impact on more than one area of the facility. In addition, there is a dedicated emergency intercom system to provide follow-up information during a widespread Refinery incident. Each operating area of the Refinery has a local alarm system for incidents within their operating units. Operators routinely carry in-plant two-way radios used for normal and emergency communications.

Employees and contractors, who do not respond to an emergency, are trained in the Refinery EAP. Persons who are inside, or near, a building are instructed to shelter-in-place inside the building. Any individual who is not in, or near, a building is instructed to proceed via a safe route to a designated assembly site. There are designated assembly sites for both local area emergencies and for a Refinery-wide emergency. The senior Refinery employee at any building or assembly site is responsible for collecting names of the persons present and communicating them to the Chevron Fire Department Dispatcher.

For hazardous material spills or releases with potential offsite impacts (or me

eting other reporting criteria), CCHMP, the Richmond Fire Department, and other agencies are notified immediately. If appropriate, the CCHMP will activate the CWS to alert the community. The CWS consists of several components as follows.

- Sirens. Initially, four sirens may be activated by Chevron to provide a loud audible signal throughout the cities of Richmond and San Pablo. Twenty sirens are available and can be activated by CCHMP. Upon hearing the sirens, residents are advised to proceed indoors to shelter-in-place and turn on their TV or radio to obtain further instructions or more information about the incident.

- Telephone Emergency Notification System. The TENS system calls households and businesses and transmits short messages about the incident and recommended protective actions.

- Media. An initial warning, updates, instructions, and an all-clear is distributed to the community through radio, television, social media, and cable by CCHMP when there is no longer a potential danger to the community.

F. Planned Changes to Improve Safety  
Chevron Richmond Refinery is dedicated to implementing projects that reduce the potential of catastrophic releases at the facility. A sampling of projects that will have significant impact are listed below.

Planned changes to improve safety may initiate from facility PHA recommendations, internal and external audits, incident investigation findings, employee suggestions, latent conditions findings, seismic assessments, and mechanical integrity testing and inspections. 

- The Richmond Refinery continues to develop and update Fixed Equipment Asset Strategies to optimize mechanical availability and to prevent/mitigate loss of containment in fixed equipment. An asset strategy is the documented plan for operating, monitoring and maintaining the fixed equipment. An asset strategy identifies applicable damage mechanisms and determines the need for operating limits known as integrity operating windows.
- Metallurgy upgrades

for various piping systems are being made to optimize inspection requirements for various damage mechanisms.
- Enhanced processes focused on routine activities are being implemented to increase fluency around safeguard management for high-risk activities and to enhance the sharing of best practices. 
- Training is underway to utilize critical start work checks for high-risk work activities. 
- The Refinery has installed vibration protection shut down systems on various types of rotating equipment.  This data is being made available for routine monitoring and trending to help predict degradation to prevent or mitigate failures.  
- The Refinery is implementing mechanical seal upgrades to centrifugal pumps based on severity of service and reliability performance.  
- The Refinery continues to conduct Procedural PHAs to identify and mitigate potential error traps associated with operating work instructions. The current focus is on emergency, startup and shutdown procedures.
